unnormalised: **Environmental News: Rethinking Waste Management in India**
normalised: **Environmental News: Rethinking Waste Management in India**

unnormalised: New Delhi – India faces a growing waste management crisis, impacting both public health and the environment. Dr. Sharma at IIT-Madras highlights the urgent need for improved segregation at source, emphasizing that mixed waste significantly hinders recycling efforts.
normalised: New Delhi – India faces a growing waste management crisis, impacting both public health and the environment. Doctor Sharma at I I T-Madras highlights the urgent need for improved segregation at source, emphasizing that mixed waste significantly hinders recycling efforts.

unnormalised: Currently, only a fraction of the estimated 62 million tonnes of waste generated annually is processed effectively. Landfills are overflowing, leading to soil and water contamination.
normalised: Currently, only a fraction of the estimated sixty two million tonnes of waste generated annually is processed effectively. Landfills are overflowing, leading to soil and water contamination.

unnormalised: The "Swachh Bharat Mission" has spurred some progress, but experts argue for a more decentralized approach. Ward-level composting and biogas plants are crucial. The focus should shift from "waste disposal" to "resource recovery."
normalised: The "Swachh Bharat Mission" has spurred some progress, but experts argue for a more decentralized approach. Ward-level composting and biogas plants are crucial. The focus should shift from "waste disposal" to "resource recovery."

unnormalised: Innovative solutions are emerging, such as using plastic waste in road construction (already implemented on some stretches of the Delhi-Meerut Expressway) and converting organic waste into valuable compost for agricultural purposes.
normalised: Innovative solutions are emerging, such as using plastic waste in road construction (already implemented on some stretches of the Delhi-Meerut Expressway) and converting organic waste into valuable compost for agricultural purposes.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the government is promoting Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) to hold manufacturers accountable for the end-of-life management of their products. A recent pilot project in Mumbai saw Rs. 5 lakhs recovered from electronic waste recycling in a 1000 sq ft area. It is estimated that this will increase in coming years. Awareness campaigns, especially in rural areas, are also vital. The collective action can pave the way for a cleaner and healthier India.
